oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Death of General Pakenham
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving depicting the death of General Edward M. Pakenham at the Battle of New Orleans. Scene of the battle, with two men on horseback. Pakenham being carried by others in the center of the scene. Explosions over the American forces behind "Line Jackson" in the background.

Before leading the British forces at New Orleans, Pakenham fought against Napoleon in the Peninsular War (1807-1814), and took part in the Battles of Bussaco, Fuentes de Onoro, and Salamanca. In September 1814, Pakenham took over command of the British troops in North America. He was also the brother-in-law of Arthur Wellesley, First Duke of Wellington, who would later defeat Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo on June 18, 1815.
